p: The antibacterial potential of different M. vulgare extracts (ethyl acetate, diethyl ether, and 1-butanol) was tested on four strains of bacteria: Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Proteus vulgaris, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The antibacterial activity of different fractions performed on solid agar medium showed little or no effect. This implies that the antibacterial activity proved with crude extract of M. vulgare was likely induced by synergistic action in chemical ingredients present in the extracts [ 97]. The methanolic extract of M. vulgare showed a significant antimicrobial activity against Escherichia coli, Bacillus subtilis, Staphylococcus aureus, S. epidermidis, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Proteus vulgaris, and Candida albicans [ 59].
